speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We're here with Brett Anderson and we'll be hearing about autistic-like traits and positive schizotypy as diametric specializations of the predictive mind.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: There will be first a presentation followed by a discussion segment.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So if you're watching live, feel free to add any comments or questions.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And Brett, thank you again for joining and on with the presentation.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: All right.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thank you, Daniel, for having me.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, yeah, this is a paper that was published this earlier this month.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so before I get into the paper, I should probably introduce myself just a little bit.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I am an evolutionary psychology student at the University of New Mexico.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: My research mainly has to do with something called the diametric model of autism and psychosis, which I'll talk more about that here in just a minute.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I am not trained in active inference or predictive processing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I came to this because I was looking for a theory that could explain variation along this autism-schizotype continuum, and I'll say what that is here in just a minute.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I came across Sanders, Vandekrois, and colleagues 2014, their paper about autism published in Psychological Review.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And it was through that paper that I sort of came to write this paper because I realized at some point that that was the theory I was looking for and that the opposite configuration of what they put forward.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they said that autism results from giving an inflexibly high weight to sensory input.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And what I realized through reading that paper and reading some other stuff around the topic,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: was that giving an inflexibly low weight to sensory input does a really good job of explaining the other side of that continuum.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so that's what this paper is about.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I'm putting forward
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: an explanation for a continuum of individual differences.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So just an idea of what I'm going to talk about here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I'm going to talk about the diametric model of autism and psychosis, what it is, what some of the evidence for it is, how it manifests in non-clinical populations, which is what my research mainly focuses on.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we refer to that as the autism schizotypy continuum.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then the hypothesis that I put forward in this paper, which has to do with explaining variation along this continuum due to trade-offs in precision weighting, due to precision weighting.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then I'll talk about some implications for predictive processing and active reference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the diametric model of autism and psychosis was first put forward by Crespi and Badcock, Bernie Crespi and Christopher Badcock in a 2008 BBS paper.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It is very simply put, just the idea that autism spectrum conditions and psychosis spectrum conditions are cognitive and genetic opposites.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Before I get into some of the evidence for it, I want to at least address what I think is the most common objection.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I hear it all the time, which is that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: How can the diametric model be true, given that some people who are diagnosed with an autism spectrum condition experience psychosis and vice versa, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So there's comorbidity between these disorders.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: How can this diametric model be the case, be true?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: i have a whole video about that on my youtube channel i might put the link in the comments to this to this youtube video but basically the response to this objection is just to point out that dsm categories are extremely heterogeneous so within each dsm category you're going to find multiple etiologies but that may be totally unrelated to each other in some cases so for example you could have somebody diagnosed with an autism spectrum condition
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that uh is is diagnosed with that mainly because for example they have like a language condition they have maybe a language delay and that causes a communicative a communication problem and then they get the autism diagnosis and it's not supposed to happen that way but it definitely does happen that way and so that would be different from somebody who has a more classical presentation with restricted and repetitive behaviors and so on and so that person
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: their etiology may have nothing whatsoever to do with the diametric model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So basically, given the heterogeneity of these conditions, we don't expect to have any precise theory that's going to explain every case of the condition, and that includes the diametric model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what is some of the evidence for the diametric model?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I think the best evidence for it is just to point out all of the diametrically related characteristics on either side of this, what's meant to be a continuum.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So with autism spectrum conditions,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's evidence that paternally expressed genes promote autism.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we get two copies of every gene.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We get one from our mom and one from our dad.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There are a subset of genes that are called imprinted genes.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And with those genes, you only express one of those copies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you might express the copy only from your dad.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's a paternally expressed gene.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Paternally expressed genes, when they're hyperexpressed, tend to promote autism spectrum conditions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We see overgrowth in autism, especially in infancy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: hypermentalizing which is reduced attribution of mental states to other people reduced imagination hyper systemizing relative right hemisphere dysfunction increased cancer rates which is related to the genomic imprinting issue and we also see a sex difference where men tend to be higher in autistic-like traits and they tend to be diagnosed with autism more often
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And on the psychosis side of things, we see a lot of opposite characteristics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we see evidence that maternally expressed genes promote psychosis spectrum conditions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We see undergrowth, especially in infancy, hypermentalizing, which is increased attribution of mental states to other people, often that manifests as paranoia, increased imagination, apophenia, which is predisposition to false positives, relative left hemisphere dysfunction,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: reduced cancer rates, at least with schizophrenia.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And we also see a sex difference with positive schizotypy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So women tend to be higher in positive schizotypy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If we're talking about psychosis, so men tend to be, so the type of psychosis that men tend to present with tends to be more often degenerative schizophrenia, whereas women tend to present more with acute psychosis, which seems to have more of a relation to the diametric model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now what this paper is focused on is how the diametric model manifests in non-clinical populations.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we talk about autistic-like traits on one end of this continuum and positive schizotypy on the other.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so the hypothesis put forward in this paper is not primarily about dysfunction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's not primarily about explaining mental disorders or mental conditions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's about explaining a continuum of individual differences that we all fall somewhere along.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so this is referred to as the autism schizotypy continuum.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the autistic side, on the side associated with autistic-like traits, we see hypomentalizing, reduced imagination, increased systemizing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They tend to be relatively poor at noisy pattern detection, although they're very good at pattern detection when there's not a lot of noise in the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We see this narrow focused attention style.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And people high in autistic-like traits are overrepresented among engineers and other technical professions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the positive schizotypy side, we see hypermentalizing, increased imagination, reduced systemizing, apophenia, and this more broad, distractible attention style, and they tend to be overrepresented among artists and other creative professions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so the hypothesis that I put forward to try to explain variation along this continuum, I refer to it as the precision weighting of sensory input hypothesis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As I'm sure everybody listening to this knows, precision weighting underlies the allocation of attention.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you can adjust the precision that you're giving to sensory input in order to account for noise in the input.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And Van de Kroys and colleagues in their 2014 paper published in Psychological Review, this was not the only.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So there was a few papers published around this time that were sort of talking about this idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Theirs was the first to really put it forward in full detail.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they argued that autism spectrum disorders are caused by giving an inflexibly high weight to sensory prediction errors.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And my paper simply extends this hypothesis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm arguing that there is a continuum of individual differences characterized by people who give a relatively high weight to sensory input on one side that's associated with autism and autistic-like traits, and people who give a relatively low weight to sensory input on the other side, which is associated with positive schizotyping.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And these differences are going to be associated with leaning towards overfitting sensory input, which is what happens in autism, and leaning towards underfitting sensory input.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that underfitting can explain some of the features of positive schizotypy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so just to give a visual demonstration of this.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is a very simplified visual demonstration, but the dots here are sensory input, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the line is the model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if you're overfitting, if you're leaning towards giving a high weight to sensory input, you're going to end up fitting your model too precisely to the data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that means that you're going to incorporate.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So a lot of that variation in the model is noise.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You're going to end up incorporating noise into your model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The opposite problem that you can have
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: is instead of giving too much weight to the sensory input, you're giving too much weight to your hypothesis about the input.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you're kind of imposing your hypothesis onto the model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You're imposing your prediction onto the input.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in this example, on the right hand side of the screen, the top down prediction is that the data is linear.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if you give too much weight to that prediction, you can end up imposing a linear model onto the data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And something like this, I will argue, is going on in positive schizotypy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then there is some optimal balance that you're going to find that is going to give you the best chance of finding the pattern underlying the data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Importantly, that balance is never the same or it's not stable.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it depends on how much noise is in the data, depends on how much you want to generalize from the data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so there is no single optimal solution, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There are always trade-offs associated with this.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so these are the differences that I am going to argue that I can explain with this hypothesis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So differences along the autism-schizotypy continuum, these include bottom up versus top down influences on perception and cognition, hypomentalizing versus hypermentalizing,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Reduced imagination versus increased imagination.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And everything on the left here is associated with the autistic-like traits.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then narrow, detailed attention versus broad, distractible attention.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Apophenia, which is associated with positive schizotypy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Systemizing, which is associated with autism and autistic-like traits.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then differences in the propensity for exploration.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we're going to go through all of these and show how this hypothesis may be able to account for them.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So with bottom up versus top down influences on perception, Crespi and Dinsdale in a 2019 paper reviewed evidence for diametric susceptibility to the rubber hand illusion.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So most people probably know what the rubber hand illusion is.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Got a little visual thing on the right hand side that shows what it is.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So with the rubber hand illusion, you have your real hand hidden by some screen or something.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And a rubber hand is placed in front of you where you think the real hand is going to go.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: the experimenter will take a feather or something and they will stroke your real hand at the same time as they stroke the rubber hand and that will produce the illusion that the rubber hand belongs to you and oftentimes at the end of the experiment they'll take a hammer and slam it down on the rubber hand and you'll jump and all that so you really you really do sort of think that the hand is yours uh what Crespi and Dinsdale reviewed evidence for is that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Oh, before I get to that, so Jakob Howey, I think that's how you say that, say his name, Jakob Howey in his book suggested that the illusion works because of the top-down prior belief that systematically related properties, in this case seeing a hand being stroked and feeling your own hand being stroked at the same time, are very likely to be causally related.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so what that means...
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: is that susceptibility to the illusion should be facilitated by giving more weight to your top-down priors.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So a relative overweighting of top-down priors should facilitate susceptibility to the illusion, and decreased susceptibility should be facilitated by giving more weight to bottom-up sensor input.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In that case, we would expect for autism and autistic-like traits to be associated with reduced susceptibility and positive schizotypy and psychosis to be associated with more susceptibility, and that is what Crespi and Dinsdale find.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They find that autism is associated with reduced susceptibility and vice versa for positive schizotypy and predisposition to psychosis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Moving on to mentalizing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So within the predictive processing framework, mentalizing or theory of mind is thought to result from the use of relatively abstract or high-level predictions, priors to predict other people's behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so again, sort of the same principle as the last time, if that's the case, we would expect an overweighting of bottom-up input relative to priors should result in hypomentalizing or reduced attribution of mental states to other people.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And an overweighting of priors should result in the opposite of hypermentalizing or giving an increased attribution of mental states to other people.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And of course, that is what we find associated with the autism schizotypy continuum.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This was one of the things that van der Kroys and colleagues talked about in their 2014 paper, but the opposite positive schizotypy does result in the opposite finding.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So next up is imagination.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: uh andy clark in a 2013 paper he argued that we we go into our imagination when we should when we sufficiently turn down the weight that we're giving to proprioceptive sensory input and so when we do that we are now dealing with our top-down predictions sort of offline right unmoored from the sensory input
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what this should mean is that if you're giving an inflexibly high weight to sensory input, that should make it more difficult to turn down that weight enough to go into your imagination.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If you're giving an inflexibly low weight to sensory input, this should mean that you will find it easier to go into your imagination.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that is we do find this difference along the autism schizotype continuum.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So people high in autistic like traits.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They have imaginative deficits often and people high in positive schizotype.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They do better on tasks that at least purportedly measure imagination, like divergent thinking tasks.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's evidence that they spend more time daydreaming and mind wandering.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And of course, they're also overrepresented among artists and creative professions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Moving on to attention.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Abu Akle and colleagues in a couple papers in 2017 and 2018 demonstrated diametric attention styles for people high in positive schizotypy and people high in autistic-like traits.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What they showed
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: especially in the 2018 paper, people high in autistic-like traits do better on a task where they had to ignore salient distractors, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the task was essentially they had to focus on something on the screen and they had to ignore salient distractors that would pop up in the periphery and that facilitated them doing better on the task.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: On the other hand, people high in positive schizotypy
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: did better on a task that was facilitated by the opposite, by being distracted by the things in that periphery.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we see this sort of focused attention style with autism, and we see this more diffuse, distractible attention style with positive schizotypy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There is other evidence for this, and I reviewed that in the paper if you want to look at that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the question is, how can the PSI hypothesis account for this?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I think this one, even though it should, you might think it's the most straightforward one because precision weighting is about attention and this is attention.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's actually, I think, the least straightforward one.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the reason why is because
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It does seem somewhat intuitive that if you're being bombarded sort of by highly precise sensory prediction errors, which is what we argue happens in autism, you might think that would make you more distractible and vice versa for positive schizotypy, since they're only paying attention to relatively large prediction errors that might make them less distractible.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That isn't the case, but...
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It'll take a little bit of unpacking to explain why, and I'm going to use an analogy here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're going to use what I'm calling the fire department analogy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you can imagine that you have two fire departments.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We'll just call them fire department A and fire department B. And there are three kinds of fires that you could have.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you could have small fires, medium fires, and large fires.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And these departments...
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: receive calls about the fires but they are not told how big the fires are right so they're they get a call they're told that there's a fire at this location but they're not told whether it's a small medium or large fire they're just told that there's a fire
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Department A has a policy where they receive calls about all kinds of fires.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they receive calls about small, medium, and large fires.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And Department B has a policy where they only receive calls about large fires.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they don't take calls about small and medium fires.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I'm arguing that this is basically equivalent, within this analogy, to giving a high weight to sensory input for Department A, which they take calls about all fires.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And as Van de Kruys and colleagues pointed out in their 2014 paper,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: When you're giving a high weight to sensory input, you're treating all of these sensory prediction errors as if they're all important.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The problem with that, of course, is that not all sensory prediction errors are actually important.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Department B, who only receives calls about large fires, this is equivalent to giving a low weight to sensory input.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So which strategy works better?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That depends on the context.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if there are more fires than you can put out at a given time, if the whole city catches fire at once, Department B works better.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Because in that case, you actually don't want to pay attention to the small fires.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You only want to pay attention to the large fires.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You want to ignore the details.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If there's not that many fires at a time, you don't want to ignore small fires.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You want to pay attention to the small fires.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So Department A works better in that context.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now imagine that these two departments are in the midst of putting out a particularly large and important fire.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They receive a call about a new fire, and the question here is what should they do in relation to this call?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Department A should maintain focus on the current fire.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's because when they receive a call, they don't know whether it's small, medium, or large, and it's more likely to be small or medium.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So they should ignore the call, maintain focus on their current task.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Department B should be more willing to allocate resources to the new fire.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They know that it's a large fire because they only receive calls about large fires, so they should be more willing to redirect their attentional resources.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is my argument for why we see this attentional difference along the autism-schizotypic continuum.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: People high in autistic-like traits have learned that the peripheral prediction errors are very likely to be unimportant and that they should focus in on the task at hand, that learning probably happens unconsciously.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: People high in positive schizotypy have learned the opposite.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If they receive a prediction error on the periphery, they've learned to assume that it's important because they only pay attention to important prediction errors.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This analogy is what I'm using to explain this attentional difference along the autism schizotypy continuum.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So moving on to systemizing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So people high in autistic-like traits and people with an autism spectrum condition are often very skilled at learning about rules-based systems.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this would be something like a computer programming language.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Most of mathematics falls under this category.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They tend to be very good at these things.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If you remember, you know, overfitting results from incorporating noise into your predictive model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The thing about a rules-based system is that there is no noise in that system.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If it's truly rules-based, then when you put in a certain input, you get the same output every time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It can be an extremely complex, these can be extremely complex rules, like there are with computer programming languages, but they're extremely precise.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so that highly precise cognitive perceptual style that comes with giving a high weight to sensory input is going to facilitate the systemizing ability with autism and autistic-like traits.

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It might be highly complex, but there's no noise.

text: If you're giving a high weight to sensory input, you can fit your model as precisely as you want to this pattern.

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: People high in positive schizotypy may, again, they may attempt to impose a pattern onto this data because they're giving more weight to the top-down assumption and less weight to the bottom-up input.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I think this is the last one.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I might finish a little early.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Exploitation, exploration.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we do see evidence
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: OK, so yeah, so deciding whether to exploit current opportunities or search for new ones through exploration is a fundamental trade off that faces all organisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And there is evidence that people high in positive schizotypy are more exploratory than people high in autistic like traits.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, for example, they are higher in the personality traits of openness and extroversion.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Colin DeYoung and some of his colleagues have argued that those two traits form a higher order trait called plasticity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And DeYoung has argued that plasticity represents the general tendency towards exploration.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's some evidence for differences in exploratory tendency.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We also see differences in sensation seeking associated with this.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So sensation seeking has also been argued to be an indicator of exploratory tendency.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So Kibberstein and colleagues in a 2019 paper said this.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They said that a large but resolvable error signal informs the agent that the environment offers the opportunity to resolve uncertainty.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That opportunity to resolve uncertainty makes exploration an attractive option.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The issue is,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So if you're giving an inflexibly high weight to sensory input, what that means is that you're not seeing large differences between the prediction errors that you're receiving.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Giving a low weight to sensory input means that people high in positive schizotypy
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: only tend to pay attention to large prediction errors.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And these large prediction errors are more likely to incentivize exploration.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They represent a greater potential information gain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so people high in autistic-like traits, we see that autism is associated with restricted and repetitive behaviors and relatively narrow interests.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that's a reflection of this reduced exploration.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Yeah, so like I said before, giving a high weight to sensory input means that most prediction errors are going to be treated as relatively equal and in importance.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And as Van de Kroys and colleagues pointed out in the 2014 paper, if each prediction error is as important as the next, it is more difficult to estimate where predictive process can be made.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And therefore, exploration is not as enticing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This comes with a benefit, however.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: because the decreased exploration that's associated with autistic-like traits is also why they tend to be more competent specialists.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They tend to specialize on one highly particular domain and sort of drill deep into one thing instead of spreading out their options over many things.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They are less likely to be distracted by emergent opportunities.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what are some of the implications of this hypothesis?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So like I said, van der Kroijs and colleagues, their 2014 theory about autism should not be seen as being just a theory about autism, but rather as a basis for a theory about individual differences in general.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Because in addition to people who give an inflexibly high weight to sensory input, I've argued here that there are people who also give an inflexibly low weight to sensory prediction errors, and those are people high in positive schizotypy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this, just as a reminder, this should not be thought of in terms of dysfunction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It is a continuum of individual differences that we all fall somewhere along, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this is just a continuum that will occur in non-clinical populations as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this paper was an initial attempt to sketch the evidence and implications of this idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There is still room for an empirical research program to test and extend this idea, and that's what I'm going to do with the rest of my PhD, most likely, and theoretical work on its implications.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I am an evolutionary psychologist, so I should talk a little bit about some evolutionary implications.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The autism-schizotypy continuum is a highly heritable source of individual differences.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We know that autism and schizophrenia, for example, have a heritability of about 0.8, so they're very heritable.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This means that they're going to be highly responsive to selection pressures.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And if this hypothesis that I put forward here is correct, my contention is that this continuum is very likely equivalent, or at least analogous, to specialist generalist continuums elsewhere in biology.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That is because the precise perceptual style in autism is going to facilitate specializing for highly particular domains.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We do see this with autism.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They tend to have relatively narrow interests, but that allows them to become very specialized in some particular domain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The imprecise perceptual style with positive schizotypy is going to facilitate picking up on these more noisy patterns, and noisy patterns tend to be more generalizable.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They tend to generalize across context a little bit better.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So there are models from theoretical biology that have been used to understand how specialist generalist continuums like this can evolve.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And basically, if I was going to extract a general principle from these models, what they tend to argue is that if you have periods of relative stability punctuated occasionally by periods of upheaval, so if you have fluctuating selection pressures, this can maintain a heritable continuum of individual differences like this one.
